ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to read and write research papers
i learned SO much about writing a scientific paper properly and how to conduct a study
How to write an APA-style psychology research paper -- very helpful for psych majors!
How to conduct research using Qualtrics; cite literature; and review of SPSS
Taking this class really helped me write the methods section of my thesis and I am really happy to have taken this course this term.
How to write a research paper and conduct research.
Improved my technical skills for writing psychology papers, especially with APA formatting.
I learned how to be a more concise writer, how to design a study, how to conduct a study through qualtrics, and how to write a research paper.
I developed a stronger understanding of how to conduct research and how to do writeups in APA format.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
- LESS WORK 
- clearer deadlines
the organization of the class was really good and we received a lot of feedback on assignments.

Strengths -- learned greatly through practice; creating my own study and writing it all up!
Weaknesses -- not a fan of the "flipped classroom" model. We rarely discussed what we learned in the textbook, instead, class time was often used to work independently on our projects. I would have much rather preferred to do that work on my own outside of class (since it can be done alone) and class time used to talk about the textbooks. I think this would have also made the midterm (the only exam we had in the class) easier.

Feedback wasn't always provided in a timely way and worksheets were usually outdated or inaccurate. Writing two studies up was a good experience, but I wish it had only been one because it was so much work.

This is a pre-req class that you should take before taking other psych classes, if you can. It helps your writing, especially the annoying nitty gritty bits. 
The lectures were good, and it was fun to do our own research. 
However, we were very much confused as to what we should have been doing in the beginning of the semester, since the professor was also getting familiar with the course she's teaching. The textbook is horrible, and please don't force us to spend that much money on materials that'd be widely available for free.

The ability to carry out our own research was invaluable to my understanding of psychology. However, the class relies heavily on a textbook in the first half which largely recaps the things learned in other classes and it would be helpful to be taught the most important material instead of having to do all of the inquisitive modules independently. The instructions for assignments are also very detailed and clear.

Strengths: very well organized, clear deadlines and guidance for assignments 

Weaknesses: sometimes the in-class assignments that i had to finish at home/ homework assignments made it hard to spend enough time on the weekly writing assignments during the week.
Strengths were the instructor's enthusiasm and willingness to help. Weaknesses were that it felt a bit disorganized at times and the work wasn't always spread out very evenly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: only if required
yes! my writing has improved a lot through this course and it is absolutely necessary to take if you are a psyc major
For psych majors it is required but very useful!
Only take if you must lots of work and disorganized.
It's a pre-req... so take it as soon as you can.
Not unless you have to take it for the major-- it develops very specific psychology skills and you have to do a lot of fairly repetitive work for it.
Yes, I really learned a lot and now  feel a lot more confident about conducting research.
